ex1.description: Lets see some examples to explain this. Suppose that $L_1 = \{$fish, dog, carrot$\}$ and that $L_2 = \{$rot, g$\}$.
ex1.question: What words in $L_1$ end with some string from $L_2$?

ex1b.description:
The right quotient $L_1 \backslash L_2 = \{x\ |\ xy \in L_1$ for some $\ y \in L_2\}$

$L_1 = \{$fish, carrot, dog$\}$, $L_2 = \{$rot, g$\}$.
ex1b.question: What are the strings in $L_1 \backslash L_2$?
correctFeedback: 'car' is what is left after cutting off 'rot' from 'carrot', and 'do' is left after cutting off 'g' from 'dog'.
incorrectFeedback: You want the strings that you get by cutting off the part in $L_2$ that is at the end of a word in $L_1$. Do this for any strings of $L_1$ that end in either 'rot' or 'g'. There are two such words in $L_1$, and you want just what is left after the matching ending is removed.

ex2.description: Lets try another example. Suppose that $L_1 = \{$carrot, parrot, rot$\}$ and that $L_2 = \{$rot$\}$.
ex2.question: What are the words in $L_1$ that end with words in $L_2$?

ex2b.description:
The right quotient $L_1 \backslash L_2 = \{x\ |\ xy \in L_1$ for some $\ y \in L_2\}$

$L_1 = \{$carrot, parrot, rot$\}$, $L_2 = \{$rot$\}$.
ex2b.question: What is $L_1 \backslash L_2$?
incorrectFeedback: You want the strings that you get by cutting off 'rot' (the only string in $L_2$) from each string in $L_1$ that ends in 'rot' (which is all of them). If we cut off the whole string, what is left is $\lambda$.

ex3.question: What is $L_1 \backslash L_2$?
incorrectFeedback: This is just a little tricky, because it shows that multiple strings from $L_2$ can operate on a given string from $L_1$. So there are two strings in the answer for this example.

ex4.description: Suppose that $L_1 = \{$cab, dab$\}$ and that $L_2 = \{$b, ab$\}$.
ex4.question: What are the words in $L_1 \backslash L_2$?

lambda.description: Remember that $L_1 \backslash L_2 = \{x\ |\ xy \in L_1$ for some $\ y \in L_2\}$. And note that $\lambda$ is a perfectly good string, and could be a member of either $L_1$ or $L_2$.
lambda.question: If $\lambda \in L_2$, which of the following is a part of $L_1 \backslash L_2$?

complexex.description: Here is our last example. Suppose that $L_1 = \{a^*b^* \cup b^*a^*\}$ and that $L_2 = \{b^n\ |\ n$ is even, $n > 0 \}$.
complexex.question: What is $L_1 \backslash L_2$?
correctFeedback: Make sure that you really understand why before going on.

different.description: Assume that we have a DFA called $M$ that accepts $L_1$. Our goal is to construct a DFA that accepts $L_1 \backslash L_2$, and we will call this machine $M'$. It turns out that $M' = (Q, \Sigma, \delta, q_0, F')$ where $M = (Q, \Sigma, \delta, q_0, F)$.
different.question: What is the only difference between $M$ (the DFA for $L_1$) and $M'$ (the DFA for $L_1 \backslash L_2$)?

q0.description: Let us test every state to see if it has a walk labled with strings $\in L_2 = \{b^m\ |\ m \ge 1 \}$ to any final state
q0.question: Is there a walk to a final state labeled with one or more $b$'s for $q_0$?
incorrectFeedback: It is not possible to get to a final state when starting at q0 without including an 'a' character.

q0final.description: The algorithm is: for each state $q_i$, if there is a walk labeled with strings $\in L_2$ to a final state in $M$, we mark $q_i$ as final state.
q0final.question: Should $q_0$ be labeled as a final state?

q1.description: Let us test every state to see if it has a walk labled with strings $\in L_2 = \{b^m\ |\ m \ge 1 \}$ to any final state
q1.question: Is there a walk to a final state labeled with one or more $b$'s for $q_1$?

q1final.description: The algorithm is: for each state $q_i$, if there is a walk labeled with strings $\in L_2$ to a final state in $M$, we mark $q_i$ as final state.
q1final.question: Should $q_1$ be a final state?

q2.description: Let us test every state to see if it has a walk labled with strings $\in L_2 = \{b^m\ |\ m \ge 1 \}$ to any final state
q2.question: Is there a walk to a final state labeled with one or more $b$'s for $q_2$?

q2final.description: The algorithm is: for each state $q_i$, if there is a walk labeled with strings $\in L_2$ to a final state in $M$, we mark $q_i$ as final state.
q2final.question: Should $q_2$ be a final state?

q3.description: Let us test every state to see if it has a walk labled with strings $\in L_2 = \{b^m\ |\ m \ge 1 \}$ to any final state
q3.question: Is there a walk to a final state labeled with one or more $b$'s for $q_3$?

q3final.description: The algorithm is: for each state $q_i$, if there is a walk labeled with strings $\in L_2$ to a final state in $M$, we mark $q_i$ as final state.
q3final.question: Should $q_3$ be a final state?

q4.description: Let us test every state to see if it has a walk labled with strings $\in L_2 = \{b^m\ |\ m \ge 1 \}$ to any final state
q4.question: Is there a walk to a final state labeled with one or more $b$'s for $q_4$?
correctFeedback: Of course not. This was the trap state, so there is no path out to any final state in $M$.

q4final.description: The algorithm is: for each state $q_i$, if there is a walk labeled with strings $\in L_2$ to a final state in $M$, we mark $q_i$ as final state.
q4final.question: Should $q_4$ be a final state?

q5.description: Let us test every state to see if it has a walk labled with strings $\in L_2 = \{b^m\ |\ m \ge 1 \}$ to any final state
q5.question: Is there a walk to a final state labeled with one or more $b$'s for $q_5$?

q5final.description: The algorithm is: for each state $q_i$, if there is a walk labeled with strings $\in L_2$ to a final state in $M$, we mark $q_i$ as final state.
q5final.question: Should $q_5$ be a final state?

lastex.description: Let's do one last example. Suppose that $L_1 = \{a^*baa^*\}$ and $L_2 = \{ab^*\}$. What is $L_1 \backslash L_2$?
lastex.question: Which DFA should we build first?

q0again.description: The algorithm is: for each state $q_i$, if there is a walk labeled with strings $\in L_2$ to a final state in $M$, we mark $q_i$ as final state. $L_1 = \{a^*baa^*\}$ and $L_2 = \{ab^*\}$.
q0again.question: Let $L_0'$ to be the language that represented by the DFA where $q_0$ is the start state. Can this machine accept anything in $L_2$? (If so, then $q_0$ should be a final state.)

q1again.description: The algorithm is: for each state $q_i$, if there is a walk labeled with strings $\in L_2$ to a final state in $M$, we mark $q_i$ as final state. $L_1 = \{a^*baa^*\}$ and $L_2 = \{ab^*\}$.
q1again.question: Let $L_1'$ to be the language that represented by the DFA where $q_1$ is the start state. Can this machine accept anything in $L_2$? (If so, then $q_1$ should be a final state.)

q2again.question: Let $L_2'$ to be the language that represented by the DFA where $q_2$ is the start state. Can this machine accept anything in $L_2$? (If so, then $q_2$ should be a final state.)

q3again.question: Let $L_3'$ to be the language that represented by the DFA where $q_3$ is the start state. Can this machine accept anything in $L_2$? (If so, then $q_3$ should be a final state.)
